snippet: A new study has found that millions of tiny insects are potentially consuming the equivalent of 60,000 frankfurters a year on a stretch of 150 blocks of median strips in Manhattan.
abstract: Study published in journal Global Change Biology finds that millions of tiny insects play role in cleaning up garbage left by humans, potentially removing nine to 14 pounds of garbage from area equivalent to city block in course of five to eight months; research shows that insects work in tandem with larger scavengers such as rats and pigeons to pick up waste.
lead_paragraph: A new study has found that millions of tiny insects are potentially consuming the equivalent of 60,000 frankfurters a year on a stretch of 150 blocks of median strips in Manhattan.

headline.main: Bugs in Manhattan Compete With Rats for Food Refuse
headline.print_headline: Picking Up After Us a Crumb at a Time
